metadata.title: Photoelectrochemical CO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> reduction to syngas by a ZnO–CdS–Cu nanocomposite

Fig. 1 Schematic illustrations of (left) band structures of the tri-component ZnO–CdS–Cu composite and (right) the photoelectrochemical system. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Characterizations of ZnO–CdS–Cu sample. (a) XRD patterns of ZnO–CdS–Cu, ZnO–CdS, and ZnO samples. (b) SEM image, and (c) high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of the ZnO–CdS–Cu sample. Inset: TEM image of the corresponding branch. (d) Elemental mapping images. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a–c) XPS spectra of ZnO–CdS–Cu, in comparison with ZnO–Cu and CdS–Cu samples. (a) Zn 2p spectra; (b) Cd 3d spectra; and (c) Cu 2p spectra. (d) Surface valence band photoemission spectra of the ZnO–CdS–Cu, ZnO–Cu, and CdS–Cu samples. The bars in (d) indicate the centers of d-band, and the upper limit of integration is fixed to –9.0 eV in binding energy for comparison. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra. (b) CO2 temperature programmed desorption (TPD) profile. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction performances at both light-off and light-on conditions for (a) ZnO–CdS–Cu, and (b) ZnO–Cu catalysts at different applied potentials. Upper panels: Faradaic efficiency (FE) values of CO and H2 productions. Middle panels: the ratios of CO and H2 production. Lower panels: the partial current densities of CO production from the electrochemical CO2 reduction. Fig. 5 Photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction to syngas by a ZnO–CdS–Cu nanocomposite Xiaoli Gu Data curation Writing - original draft Linping Qian Writing - review & editing Supervision * Gengfeng Zheng Writing - review & editing Supervision * Laboratory of Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry and Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, China Laboratory of Advanced Materials Department of Chemistry and Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials Fudan University Shanghai 200438 China Laboratory of Advanced Materials, Department of Chemistry and Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Syngas, the mixture of CO and H2, is an important feedstock for producing methanol and other liquid fuels. Herein, we demonstrated a photoelectrochemical system by employing cadmium sulfide (CdS)-decorated zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles and Cu nanorods to boost the photoelectrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) in an aqueous solution. Structural characterizations showed that the heterostructure and interfaces of semiconductors facilitated the photo-absorption as well as the fast transfer of photogenerated carriers from the semiconductors to catalytic sites. Compared to the condition with light off, the tri-component ZnO–CdS–Cu catalyst exhibited an enhancement of 6.2 times in the CO partial current density at relatively low applied potential of –1.16 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode under ∼1 sun illumination. In addition, the ratio of CO and H2 in the products was tuned in a wide range between 0.03 and 0.53, which was beneficial for the syngas production. Keywords Photoelectrochemical CO2reduction Electrocatalysis ZnO CdS Cu Introduction The continuous depletion of fossil fuel resources and the increase of carbon dioxide (CO2) emission globally have attracted wide attention in the research community. By 2019, the CO2 level in the atmosphere has exceeded 410 ppm, which is potential of resulting a variety of environmental hazards such as greenhouse warming. The storage and conversion of excessive CO2 into other non-green-house molecules have been studied by many scientists in the past decades. Many photocatalysts and electrocatalysts have been reported for the electrochemical CO2 reduction [1–4] and water splitting [5–8]. Particularly, the photoelectrochemical (PEC) system combines both photo-energy and electricity as energy input for CO2 reduction, which has the potential of taking advantages of both energy forms to reduce the reaction potential and increase the catalytic activities. [9–13] However, substantial challenges still exist due to the inert nature of CO2 and generally low efficiency of current available catalysts. [14,15] Among the different CO2 reduction products, carbon monoxide (CO) is an important raw material and a main component in the syngas. Together with hydrogen gas (H2) co-produced from the PEC cathode half-reaction, the syngas is highly crucial for producing a variety of chemical products such as methanol. The electrochemical reduction of CO2 into CO involves the transfer of two electrons, which is kinetically more favorable than producing other reduction products (e.g. CH4, C2H4) with multiple electron transfer steps. [16–19] To date, various semiconductors including TiO2 [20], Cu2O, [21] ZnTe [22], and NiO [23], have been reported for PEC CO2 reduction. Binary and trinary component-based catalysts have also been reported to enhance the PEC CO2 reduction properties. [24] Among them, copper (Cu) based materials are attracting much interest due to their unique CO2 adsorption feature, low toxicity and relative abundancy. [25] Zinc oxide (ZnO), as a widely investigated semiconductor [26,27], has many merits including high electron mobility, low synthesis cost, and potential of facilitating CO2 adsorption for subsequent electrochemical reduction. [28] However, due to its large bandgap, the utilization of ZnO as photocatalyst is severely hindered by its poor visible light absorption [29]. Previous studies using a tandem structure of ZnO and smaller bandgap materials [30–32], such as metal chalcogenides, can effectively improve its photo-absorption in the visible range and thus enhance the conversion of solar energy to chemical energy. In spite of these progresses, the design and function of the photo-absorber, sensitizers, and surface electrocatalyst have still been limited, or particular nanostructures to enable the CO2 reduction effect are required. A general approach of the PEC CO2 reduction is still needed to be established. In this work, we reported a step-by-step approach to grow a nanocomposite of ZnO, CdS and Cu (designated as ZnO–CdS–Cu), as schematically shown in Fig. 1 . The 1-dimensional feature of the nanocomposite enables efficient charge transfer property, and the combination of these three components allows for good photo-absorption in both the UV and visible range of the solar spectrum. Furthermore, the Cu behaves as the main catalytic centers for the CO2 reduction to CO. Compared to binary ZnO–Cu and ZnO, the ZnO–CdS–Cu nanocomposite presented a clearly enhanced CO2 reduction capability upon the solar illumination. Compared to the condition with light off, the partial current density (j co) for CO product was also enhanced by a factor of 6.2 times, the ratio of CO product and H2 (from water reduction) were tuned in a wide range from 0.03 to 0.53, and suggesting the attractive capability of using this nanocomposite as both light absorber and catalyst for the PEC CO2 reduction. Results and discussion ZnO nanoparticles were first synthesized by a hydrothermal method, followed by deposition of CdS nanoparticles on its surface (Experimental section in the Supporting Information). [33,34] Afterwards, Cu was grown by a deposition method followed by thermal annealing. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was first conducted to confirm the successful growth of the designed components (Fig. 2 a). Three diffraction peaks were clearly observed at 31.8°, 34.4° and 36.3°, ascribed to (100), (002) and (101) planes of ZnO (JCPDS 36–1451), respectively. The three sharp peaks at 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1° were assigned to (111), (200) and (220) of pure copper (JCPDS 04−0836), respectively. The other three peaks at 24.8°, 26.5° and 28.2° were indexed to (100), (002) and (101) of CdS (JCPDS 41–1049), respectively. Thus, the proposed multi-component samples were synthesized as noted. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images exhibit the branch feature of ZnO–CdS–Cu sample, which consisted of a chain of nanoparticles (Fig. 2b). ZnO and CdS nanoparticles, with diameters of about 6 and 1.7 nm, respectively, were loaded on the surface of Cu branches. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images displayed the lattice resolved fringes of 0.257, 0.313 and 0.214 nm (Fig. 2c), consistent with the interplanar distances of hexagonal ZnO (002), hexagonal CdS (101), and cubic Cu (111) planes, respectively. The elemental mapping suggests that the three components of ZnO–CdS–Cu sample were uniformly distributed (Fig. 2d). The oxidation states of different elements on the ZnO–CdS–Cu surfaces were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The high-resolution Zn 2p profile revealed two peaks with binding energy of 1021.8 and 1045.0 eV (Fig. 3 a), corresponding to +2 oxidation states of Zn elements. Compared to ZnO–Cu (1021.4 and 1044.3 eV), these two peaks were shifted toward higher binding energies with 0.4 and 0.7 eV, respectively. [34] The Cd 3d and Cu 2p XPS profiles also confirmed the existence of Cd(II) and Cu(0), as well as the corresponding shifts of XPS peaks (Fig. 3 b–c). All the XPS spectra of ZnO–CdS–Cu, ZnO–Cu, ZnO–CdS, CdS–Cu, ZnO, CdS and Cu were displayed, including their Zn 2p (Fig. S1a), Cd 3d (Fig. S1b) and Cu 2p (Fig. S1c). The Zn 2p, Cd 3d and Cu 2p peak positions of ZnO–CdS–Cu showed shifts compared to those of ZnO–Cu, CdS–Cu, ZnO–CdS, ZnO, CdS and Cu samples. These shifts in the XPS binding energies suggested intimate interactions between different components. This strong electronic interaction at the interface between ZnO and Cu could lead to higher activity for CO2 activation and hydrogenation, as suggested by previous literature. [33] Furthermore, the projected densities of states (PDOS) for the d-band of the catalyst surfaces were plotted (Fig. 3d). The bonding strength between intermediates and catalysts plays an important role in tuning the catalytic performance by changing the catalyst surface electronic structure, which is determined by the values of (E − E F) with reference to the Fermi level (E F). [35] As shown, the position ranking of the d-band center with respect to the E F was down-shifted in the order of CdS–Cu (–3.51 eV) > ZnO–Cu (–3.81 eV) > ZnO–CdS–Cu (–4.87 eV). The down-shift of the d-band centers increases the donation bonding states and decreases the back-donation antibonding states, weakening the substrate − adsorbate interaction, especially the adsorption of *COOH or *CO on catalyst surfaces. Thus, the CO2 reduction activity is enhanced, with an increased release of CO product. [36] The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were conducted to determine the optical properties of these samples in the full solar wavelength range (Fig. 4 a). Compared to pure ZnO with an absorption cutoff about 400 nm, the decoration of CdS on ZnO effectively extended the absorption edge to the visible region, i.e., 560 nm. After the incorporation of Cu, the absorption edge was further extended to over 800 nm. This change was in good accord with a previous report [37] that the absorption edge in the diffuse reflectance spectra was extended to over 800 nm with the introduction of Cu in the reduced state, in contrast to Cu in the oxidized state. This observation further confirmed our statement on the existence of Cu(0), instead of Cu(I). Our UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra indicated that ZnO–CdS–Cu could be photo-excited by both UV and visible light irradiation, thus increasing the utilization of the solar energy and energy input for the subsequent photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction. The bandgap energies of the samples were extrapolated from the Tauc plots by Kubelka–Munk function: (Ahν/K)1/n = hν − Eg , where A is the absorbance, hν is the photon energy, K is a proportional constant, and Eg is the bandgap energy, respectively. [38] Since the direct allowed sample transition was used in this experiment, n = 1/2 was used for these samples. As plotted in Fig. S2 (where A/K in the function was substituted with α), the bandgap energy of pure ZnO was estimated to be 3.18 eV, which was in good accord with the reported values (i.e., 3.2 eV). [39] The bandgap of ZnO–CdS was decreased to be 2.29 eV and lower than those of ZnO and CdS (i.e., 2.4 eV), suggesting the improvement of absorption of solar energy. The CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) was conducted to evaluate the chemisorption of CO2 with the multiple component combinations. An obviously stronger chemical desorption peak was observed for ZnO–CdS–Cu than those of ZnO–CdS and pure ZnO at 350 °C (Fig. 4b), indicating ZnO–CdS–Cu presented the strongest CO2 chemisorption capability. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of these samples were investigated during the electrochemical CO2 reduction process. The Nyquist plots (Fig. S3) of all the samples showed semicircle features, among which ZnO–CdS–Cu exhibited the smallest semicircular diameter, indicating the lowest interfacial charge-transfer resistance. [18,40] The semicircular diameter of ZnO–Cu was smaller than that of pure ZnO. Thus, the interfacial charge-transfer process of ZnO–CdS–Cu nanocomposites was accelerated after the combination of Cu and CdS into ZnO, which also played a vital role during PEC CO2 reduction process. The PEC CO2 reduction measurements were carried out in a conventional three-electrode electrochemical setup and under air mass 1.5 global (AM 1.5 G) simulated sunlight (100 mW cm–2). A 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte, which was pre-saturated with a CO2 flow before tests. All the voltages reported here were converted into the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was first conducted in the voltage range between +0.24 and –1.76 V. The ZnO–CdS–Cu catalyst showed an onset voltage of about –0.071 V (defined as the potential where photocathodic current reached 0.02 mA cm–2 under AM 1.5 G illumination) with the light off, which positively shifted to +0.095 V under the light illumination (Fig. S4). This change confirmed that the increased of photo-response and photocurrent with the solar energy input. The PEC CO2 reduction reactivity was further characterized by detecting the gas reduction products by gas chromatography and liquid products by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). The 1H NMR spectra showed the information of liquid products from the ZnO–CdS–Cu sample from electrochemical CO2 reduction at –1.16 V, under light-off (Fig. S5a) and light-on (Fig. S5b) conditions in a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3. The chemical shifts of around 8.33 and 1.06 ppm corresponded to formate (HCOO–) and ethanol (CH3CH2OH), respectively. At the applied potentials from –0.96 to –1.76 V, the FE values of the liquid products (i.e. both HCOO– and CH3CH2OH) were not more than 6.4 % (Fig. S6). For ZnO–CdS–Cu, the Faradaic efficiencies (FEs) for CO and H2 (produced from HER) were measured at applied potentials between –0.96 and –1.76 V in the CO2-saturated KHCO3 electrolyte (Fig. 5 a, upper panel). When the light was off, the partial current density for the CO production was –0.51 mA cm–2 at –1.16 V, which was increased to –3.67 mA cm–2 when the light was turned on (Fig. 5a, lower panel), corresponding to an enhancement factor of 6.2 times. The competitive HER was dominant in the reaction system due to its low onset voltage. The PEC CO2 reduction was launched as the applied voltage shiftingly negatively and enhanced with the aid of solar energy input, and reached an optimal performance at –1.16 V. At a more negative potential than –1.16 V, the FE of CO production decreased, which was possibly attributed to the CO2 mass transport limit and the increased competitive HER. [41] In addition, the FE values of CO and H2 production were 30.9 % and 58.4 %, respectively, at this condition. Thus, the CO/H2 ratio was approximately 1:2 (Fig. 5a, middle panel), which was a desirable composition of syngas mixtures for methanol synthesis and Fischer–Tropsch reaction. By tuning the applied potential between –0.96 V and –1.76 V, the CO/H2 ratio was tuned in a large range between 0.03 and 0.53. In contrast, for ZnO–Cu catalyst (i.e., without CdS component), the production of CO and H2 was also measured in the range of –0.96 V and –1.76 V, and compared at both light-off and light-on conditions, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5b, the FE values for CO (upper panel), the ratio between CO and H2 (middle panel), and the partial current density for CO production (lower panel) did not show any increase, but even decrease instead. The FEs of H2 production did not show substantial variations in both light-off and light-on conditions over all the voltages. Thus, the comparison results showed that the existence of the three components of ZnO–CdS–Cu was critical for the PEC CO2 reduction activity enhancement and CO production tuning, which should mainly be ascribed to the synergy of the boosted sunlight absorption by the ZnO–CdS heterojunction, the enhanced CO2 absorption capability, and the accelerated interfacial charge-transfer process. Conclusion In summary, we have successfully demonstrated to synthesize a tri-component ZnO–CdS–Cu nanocomposite for efficient photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction for tunable syngas production. By employing the ZnO–CdS–Cu catalyst in the photoelectrochemical system, the CO partial current density was enhanced by 6.2 times under ∼ 1 sun illumination compared to the condition with light off, and the CO/H2 ratios in the products was tuned in a wide range between 0.03 and 0.53. Our experimental studies revealed the intimate interactions among these three components and the improved photo-absorption and charge transfer processes. Further developments in the synergy of various photo-responsive semiconductors and metal catalysts can open new opportunities for improving the efficiency of PEC CO2 reduction toward producing syngas and other valuable products. CRediT authorship contribution statement Xiaoli Gu: Data curation, Writing - original draft. Linping Qian: Writing - review & editing, Supervision. coredata.dc:description: Syngas, the mixture of CO and H2, is an important feedstock for producing methanol and other liquid fuels. Herein, we demonstrated a photoelectrochemical system by employing cadmium sulfide (CdS)-decorated zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles and Cu nanorods to boost the photoelectrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) in an aqueous solution. Structural characterizations showed that the heterostructure and interfaces of semiconductors facilitated the photo-absorption as well as the fast transfer of photogenerated carriers from the semiconductors to catalytic sites. Compared to the condition with light off, the tri-component ZnO–CdS–Cu catalyst exhibited an enhancement of 6.2 times in the CO partial current density at relatively low applied potential of –1.16 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode under ∼1 sun illumination. In addition, the ratio of CO and H2 in the products was tuned in a wide range between 0.03 and 0.53, which was beneficial for the syngas production.
coredata.dc:title: Photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction to syngas by a ZnO–CdS–Cu nanocomposite
